summary: Using Data to Fight Corruption and Alleviate Poverty
categories: International and Public Affairs,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Online,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Social Justice,org/ilas,org/sipa,Postdocs,Government and Public Policy,Discussion,Graduate Students,Graduate School of Arts and Sciences,Political Science
description: <p>The&nbsp;<a href="https://www.sipa.columbia.edu/academics/concentrations/economic-and-political-development" target="_blank">Economic and Political Development</a>&nbsp;(EPD) and&nbsp;<a href="https://www.sipa.columbia.edu/academics/concentrations/urban-and-social-policy" target="_blank">Urban and Social Policy</a>&nbsp;(USP) Concentrations, the&nbsp;<a href="https://ilas.columbia.edu/" target="_blank">Institute of Latin American Studies</a>&nbsp;(ILAS), the Latin American Student Association (LASA),&nbsp;the&nbsp;<a href="https://datascience.columbia.edu/" target="_blank">Data Science Institute</a>&nbsp;and the&nbsp;<a href="https://worldprojects.columbia.edu/about-obama-foundation-scholars-program" target="_blank">Columbia Obama Foundation Scholars Program</a>&nbsp;invite you to a virtual discussion on &quot;<em><strong>Using Data to Fight Corruption and Alleviate Poverty</strong></em>&quot; with&nbsp;<strong>William Jorge Dau Chamat, Mayor of Cartagena (Colombia)</strong>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<strong>Ana Maria Gonzalez-Forero, Director of International Cooperation in the Mayor&#39;s Office of Cartagena, and 2018-2019 Obama Foundation Scholar</strong>.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>Register <a href="https://events.columbia.edu/cal/event/eventView.do?b=de&amp;calPath=%2Fpublic%2Fcals%2FMainCal&amp;guid=CAL-00bbdb71-7ef78050-017e-fa0f17d8-00004976events@columbia.edu&amp;recurrenceId=" target="_blank">Here</a></p>

summary: March Narrative Medicine Rounds with Joshua Prager
categories: org/EmergencyMedicine,org/law,org/NMrounds,org/CUMCNarrativeMedicine,org/Anesthesiology,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Online,Lecture,Family-friendly,Student,Faculty,Staff,Public,Alumni,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,Panel,Postdocs,Prospective Students,Professional Development,Healthcare,Graduate Students,Mailman School of Public Health,Trainees,Grand Rounds,org/cumc_hiccc,org/cumc,Journalism,Humanities,Other
description: <h2>&quot;THE FAMILY ROE: An American Story,&quot; a conversation moderated by Dr. Carolyn Westhoff.</h2>\n<p>For our March Narrative Medicine Rounds, we are excited to host&nbsp;<a href="https://www.joshuaprager.com/" target="_blank">Joshua Prager</a>, author of&nbsp;<a href="https://bookshop.org/books/the-family-roe-an-american-story/9780393247718" target="_blank"><em>THE FAMILY ROE: An American Story</em></a>, in a conversation moderated by Dr. Carolyn Westhoff.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>Despite her famous pseudonym, &ldquo;Jane Roe,&rdquo; no one knows the truth about Norma McCorvey (1947&ndash;2017), whose unwanted pregnancy in 1969 opened a great fracture in American life. Journalist Joshua Prager spent hundreds of hours with Norma, discovered her personal papers&mdash;a previously unseen trove&mdash;and witnessed her final moments.&nbsp;<em>The Family Roe</em>&nbsp;presents her life in full. Propelled by the crosscurrents of sex and religion, gender and class, it is a life that tells the story of abortion in America. Called&nbsp;&quot;an honest glimpse into the American soul&quot; by&nbsp;<em>The New York Times</em>, and &quot;prodigiously researched, richly detailed, sensitively told&quot; by&nbsp;<em>The New Yorker</em>, the book was named one of&nbsp;<em>NPR</em>&#39;s best books of 2021, A&nbsp;<em>New York Times</em>&nbsp;notable book of 2021, and a finalist for the National Book Critics Award for Nonfiction. Prager is also the author of&nbsp;<em>The Echoing Green</em>&nbsp;(a&nbsp;<em>Washington Post</em>&nbsp;Best Book of the Year) and&nbsp;<em>100 Years</em>, a collaboration with Milton Glaser, the graphic designer who created the I&nbsp;NY logo. Prager has written for the&nbsp;<em>Atlantic</em>,&nbsp;<em>Vanity Fair</em>, the&nbsp;<em>New York Times</em>,&nbsp;and the&nbsp;<em>Wall Street Journal</em>. He was a Nieman fellow at Harvard and a Fulbright Distinguished Chair at Hebrew University, and has spoken at venues including TED and Google. He lives in New Jersey with his wife and two daughters.</p>

summary: Using the Think Bigger Method to Find Climate Change Solutions
description: <p>Business leaders are looking for that next great idea or innovation to address climate change and sustainability, but we often forget an important part:&nbsp;<em>how</em>? Where do our best ideas come from? Join us for a conversation with&nbsp;<a href="https://columbiasocialenterprise.org/civicrm/mailing/url?u=37727&amp;qid=">Professor Sheena Iyengar</a>, who will touch on how innovation &mdash; whether that be as an environmental entrepreneur, within a business or field of discipline, or in our personal lives and how we impact the environment &mdash; begins with a creative spark and the tools that can be used to find your spark of innovation to address the global climate change crisis.</p>\n<p>The Think Bigger Innovation Method utilizes decision-making theory, cognitive science, and industry practice to facilitate creativity and innovation for complex problem solving that is both novel and useful. Using cognitive science, Think Bigger provides a six-step method for innovation that is unlike any other. Whether a problem is related to social discourse, the transition to net zero, or supply chain sustainability and logistics, The Think Bigger Innovation Method fosters both interdisciplinary teamwork and constructive interactions that draw on every individual&rsquo;s experience and expertise. The method focuses on defining and refining a problem, while learning to deconstruct and verbalize that problem to surface and reduce bias. It also privileges searching outside the self, going far beyond customer insight, and exploring the history of true innovation. At its heart, Think Bigger relies on structured persistence, multi-domain research, and combinatory experimentation.</p>\n<h2><a href="https://columbiasocialenterprise.org/civicrm/event/register?id=849&amp;reset=1" target="_blank"><strong>RSVP &rarr;</strong></a></h2>

summary: Multi-Faith Fellowship
locationaddress: Earl Hall, 2980 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
description: <p>The Multi-Faith Fellowship provides the rare opportunity for genuine learning and community across faith traditions. Honesty, openness, and humility are core values that make the Multi-Faith Fellowship a unique experience in education and dialogue. Students from all schools and all traditions are welcome to join. Join us for&nbsp;dinner, discussion, and multi-faith dialogue every Wednesday night throughout the semester.&nbsp;</p>

description: <p>The Institute for the Study of Human Rights is hosting a new event:&nbsp;<em>China&#39;s Human Rights Record: What&nbsp;<strong>Can</strong>&nbsp;We Do and What&nbsp;<strong>Should</strong>&nbsp;We Do?&nbsp;</em>This conversation will be led by Jack Snyder, Robert and Ren&eacute;e Belfer Professor of International Relations, and Andrew Nathan, Class of 1919 Professor of Political Science.&nbsp;The two will discuss what Americans and other foreign citizens can do about human rights violations that are occurring in China, and whether these are things that non-Chinese citizens should do. What are our moral obligations, and what actions might be effective in influencing the human rights situation in China?</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\n<p>The event will be held on&nbsp;<strong>Thursday, March 3</strong>&nbsp;from&nbsp;<strong>12:00 - 1:00pm</strong>&nbsp;at the&nbsp;<a href="https://cgt.columbia.edu/locations/the-international-affairs-building-iab-918/" target="_blank">International Affairs Building, room 918</a>.&nbsp;</p>

summary: In Search of the Ancients: Etymology between Spain and the New World
description: <p><strong>Valeria L&oacute;pez Fadul</strong> (Wesleyan University),&nbsp;<strong>Seth Kimmel </strong>(Columbia University) and&nbsp;<strong>Pier Mattia Tommasino</strong> (Columbia University) will discuss&nbsp;the tools through which&nbsp;sixteenth-century Spanish scholars, missionaries, and officials under the patronage of the royal court sought to extract knowledge about the empire&rsquo;s American territories by researching local languages.&nbsp;</p>

summary: The Process of Purchasing a Property
description: <p>Real estate experts will provide a step-by-step guide to home ownership, while answering your questions about purchasing various types of properties (co-ops, condos, and houses). &nbsp;What type of property is right for you? How and where do you begin looking? &nbsp;What are the costs associated with home/apartment ownership? &nbsp;What happens at closing? &nbsp;</p>\n<p>Presenters: Two real estate brokers</p>

summary: Composer Portraits: Felipe Lara
locationaddress: Miller Theatre, 2960 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
description: <p>Brazilian-American composer Felipe Lara writes music that transforms and reinterprets sonic expectations. International Contemporary Ensemble, longtime advocates of Lara, perform two of his substantial recent works, including&nbsp;<em>Metafagote</em>&mdash;a work for solo bassoon and six pre-recorded spatialized bassoons that results in the creation of an astonishing soundworld.</p>

xproperties: X-BEDEWORK-REGISTRATION-GUEST-ACCESS : values : text : 	email,X-BEDEWORK-IMAGE : values : text : /public/images/ocp-202108311134-202201161029.png,X-BEDEWORK-THUMB-IMAGE : values : text : 	/public/images/ocp-202108311134-202201161029-thumb.png,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Location/Lamont-Doherty,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Type/Seminar,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Alumni,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Faculty,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Family Friendly,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Graduate Students,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Postdocs,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Prospective Students,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Public,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Staff,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Student,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Trainees,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Category/Earth Institute,X-BEDEWORK-SHORTTITLE : values : text : Ocean & Climate Seminar Series | Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory,X-BEDEWORK-SUBMITTEDBY : values : text : st3408 for Ocean and Climate Physics Seminars (agrp_OCPS),X-BEDEWORK-CALSUITE : values : text : Ocean and Climate Physics Seminars,X-BEDEWORK-ADDITIONAL-INFO : values : text : January 28th, Jesse Cusack, Rutgers University, "Plume-generated internal gravity waves as drivers of melt at LeConte Glacier, Alaska"\nAbstract:\nTIt is commonly understood that melting at marine-terminating glaciers is enhanced by the fluid velocities in the vicinity of the ice-ocean boundary. Large velocities and high melt rates are thought to occur adjacent to highly turbulent subglacial discharge plumes. However, recent observations demonstrate that melt rates are also high far away from plumes, suggesting that other ocean processes may facilitate heat and salt fluxes to the ice-ocean interface. Using extensive in situ observations, as well as idealised large eddy simulations, we demonstrate that the subglacial discharge plume emanating from LeConte Glacier, Alaska, generates an energetic internal gravity wave field. The waves are persistent in time and fill the near-glacier fjord, accounting for ~ 50 % of the total observed kinetic energy near the ice-ocean boundary during the two-week September 2018 field campaign. They are characterised by coherent oscillations in velocity of magnitude 1 - 8 cm/s with a period of ~ 10 mins (close to the local buoyancy period) and a horizontal wavelength of 150 - 200 m. The signal was identified in two separate mooring records, one of which was located within 100 m of the terminus, suggesting that internal waves have the potential to enhance melting by driving flow directly at the ice-ocean interface. Accounting for wave velocities within a commonly used melt parameterisation, which assumes shear-driven boundary layer dynamics, results in a 40 - 80 % increase in the estimated melt rate relative to ambient (no wave) conditions.,X-BEDEWORK-DESCRIPTION-FORMAT : values : text : html

summary: Dezron Douglas Quartet
locationaddress: Miller Theatre, 2960 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
description: <p>Dezron Douglas is one of the most in-demand young bassists in jazz today. He has performed and recorded with jazz luminaries such as Pharoah Sanders, Cyrus Chestnut, George Cables, Keyon Harrold, and Makaya McCraven. The New York-based composer, bandleader, and sideman was featured in Miller&#39;s&nbsp;<em>Live from Columbia</em>&nbsp;digital series over the pandemic, and now returns with his new quartet.</p>

summary: Friend2Friend Training
locationaddress: Butler Library, 535 W. 114 St., New York, NY 10027
categories: Columbia Health: Alice Health Promotion,Morningside,Type,Location,Audience,Category,Student,Events open to,org/UniversityEvents,org/universitylife,org/ColumbiaHealth,Healthcare,Graduate Students,Training
description: <p>Friend2Friend is a 3-hour skills-based training designed to help students effectively recognize and respond to others exhibiting indicators of distress. The training is focused on understanding, re-framing, referring, and self-care. Please register to attend the training.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>Link to register:&nbsp;<a href="https://bit.ly/F2F_2022" target="_blank">https://bit.ly/F2F_2022</a></p>\n<p>Columbia Health makes every effort to accommodate individuals with disabilities. If you require disability accommodations to attend an event sponsored by Columbia Health, or by the University, please contact Disability Services at (212) 854-2388 at least 5 days in advance of the event.</p>

summary: A Peek into the Future of Residential Real Estate in NYC
description: <p>Now, two years into the pandemic, many are wondering about the impact and the future of rental and purchasing trends in real estate in New York City. In a discussion important for all New Yorkers, Chris Mayer returns for another dynamic session focused on a re-cap of the past two years, along with short and long-term expectations for NYC residential real estate.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>Presenter: <a href="https://www8.gsb.columbia.edu/cbs-directory/detail/cm310">Chris Mayer</a>, Paul Milstein Professor of Real Estate, Columbia Business School</p>

summary: Microteaching Practice (for Graduate Students)
locationaddress: Butler Library, 535 W. 114 St., New York, NY 10027
description: <p>Want to practice a new in-class activity or just get some more practice before teaching in your classroom? Join peers in a&nbsp;Microteaching Practice session where you will divide into groups of 3-4 with a facilitator and take turns delivering short samples of instruction to each other. After each teaching sample, your facilitator and your peers will offer structured feedback to support your teaching. Whether you are currently teaching at Columbia or not, all graduate students looking to practice teaching are welcome to attend this Microteaching Practice session. Columbia University makes every effort to accommodate individuals with disabilities.<br />\n<br />\nContact&nbsp;ColumbiaCTL@columbia.edu&nbsp;or 212.854.1692 for accommodations. This event may be photographed. For concerns, contact&nbsp;ColumbiaCTL@columbia.edu.</p>

summary: Sound Bowl: Relax Your Mind and Body
description: <p>Sound bowl session to relax your mind and body. The sound waves from the bowl act on the energy field of your body and cause you to relax. It&rsquo;s the vibrations from the Sound Bowls that lead to its effects.</p>

summary: Multi-Faith Fellowship
locationaddress: Earl Hall, 2980 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
description: <p>The Multi-Faith Fellowship provides the rare opportunity for genuine learning and community across faith traditions. Honesty, openness, and humility are core values that make the Multi-Faith Fellowship a unique experience in education and dialogue. Students from all schools and all traditions are welcome to join. Join us for&nbsp;dinner, discussion, and multi-faith dialogue every Wednesday night throughout the semester.&nbsp;</p>

summary: Sexual Orientation and Gender Identity Rights with Ajita Banerjie
description: <p>The Human Rights Graduate Group will facilitate a panel with Ajita Banerjie, a researcher working on Sexual Orientation and Gender Identity&nbsp;rights and access to justice. She currently works with the International Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Trans and Intersex &nbsp;Association (ILGA) Asia where she leads research on SOGIESC related human rights developments in Asia.</p>\n<p>For Zoom login, register here:&nbsp;<a href="https://bit.ly/3oQb5Gi" target="_blank">https://bit.ly/3oQb5Gi</a></p>

xproperties: X-BEDEWORK-REGISTRATION-GUEST-ACCESS : values : text : 	email,X-BEDEWORK-IMAGE : values : text : /public/images/ocp-202108311134-202201161029.png,X-BEDEWORK-THUMB-IMAGE : values : text : 	/public/images/ocp-202108311134-202201161029-thumb.png,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Location/Lamont-Doherty,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Type/Seminar,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Alumni,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Faculty,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Family Friendly,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Graduate Students,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Postdocs,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Prospective Students,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Public,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Staff,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Student,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Trainees,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Category/Earth Institute,X-BEDEWORK-SHORTTITLE : values : text : Ocean & Climate Seminar Series | Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory,X-BEDEWORK-SUBMITTEDBY : values : text : st3408 for Ocean and Climate Physics Seminars (agrp_OCPS),X-BEDEWORK-CALSUITE : values : text : Ocean and Climate Physics Seminars,X-BEDEWORK-ADDITIONAL-INFO : values : text : January 28th, Jesse Cusack, Rutgers University, "Plume-generated internal gravity waves as drivers of melt at LeConte Glacier, Alaska"\nAbstract:\nTIt is commonly understood that melting at marine-terminating glaciers is enhanced by the fluid velocities in the vicinity of the ice-ocean boundary. Large velocities and high melt rates are thought to occur adjacent to highly turbulent subglacial discharge plumes. However, recent observations demonstrate that melt rates are also high far away from plumes, suggesting that other ocean processes may facilitate heat and salt fluxes to the ice-ocean interface. Using extensive in situ observations, as well as idealised large eddy simulations, we demonstrate that the subglacial discharge plume emanating from LeConte Glacier, Alaska, generates an energetic internal gravity wave field. The waves are persistent in time and fill the near-glacier fjord, accounting for ~ 50 % of the total observed kinetic energy near the ice-ocean boundary during the two-week September 2018 field campaign. They are characterised by coherent oscillations in velocity of magnitude 1 - 8 cm/s with a period of ~ 10 mins (close to the local buoyancy period) and a horizontal wavelength of 150 - 200 m. The signal was identified in two separate mooring records, one of which was located within 100 m of the terminus, suggesting that internal waves have the potential to enhance melting by driving flow directly at the ice-ocean interface. Accounting for wave velocities within a commonly used melt parameterisation, which assumes shear-driven boundary layer dynamics, results in a 40 - 80 % increase in the estimated melt rate relative to ambient (no wave) conditions.,X-BEDEWORK-DESCRIPTION-FORMAT : values : text : html

summary: Prostate Cancer: What Resources are Available to Our Communities?
description: <p>Our objective is to engage with community and faith leaders to share existing resources around prostate cancer to communities throughout NYC&nbsp;&amp; Long Island&nbsp;through NYC and Long Island. This webinar will provide an overview of prostate cancer risk, prostate cancer screening, and screening resources. We will hear from a&nbsp;medical&nbsp;doctor for a discussion about prostate cancer risk and screening, a survivor of prostate cancer will share his story, researchers who work in healthcare shared&nbsp;decision making will talk about&nbsp;their work,&nbsp;information about a mobile prostate screening van will be shared, and&nbsp;a project to develop a prostate cancer educational tool will be described. Representatives from NYC&nbsp;&amp; Long IslandCancer Centers will also share resources&nbsp;available at their sites, and a resource guide will be distributed to webinar participants. There will be time at the end of the webinar for a Q&amp;A session. Please register to join us!</p>

summary: ISSO Newly Arrived J-1 Faculty and Researchers Orientation
description: <p>This ISSO sponsored event is for Newly Arrived J-1 Faculty and Researchers at Columbia University.<br />\n<br />\nYou are invited to our Newly Arrived J-1 Faculty and Researchers Orientation. These sessions are for those who have recently arrived. The orientation covers an overview of this visa status. ISSO strongly recommends you attend. Please have your DS-2019 and passport available. <a href="https://columbiauniversity.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_sgF-zX_6RQCr5Mk5atf0FA" target="_blank">Register here</a>.</p>

xproperties: X-BEDEWORK-REGISTRATION-GUEST-ACCESS : values : text : 	email,X-BEDEWORK-IMAGE : values : text : /public/images/ocp-202108311134-202201161029.png,X-BEDEWORK-THUMB-IMAGE : values : text : 	/public/images/ocp-202108311134-202201161029-thumb.png,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Location/Lamont-Doherty,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Type/Seminar,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Alumni,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Faculty,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Family Friendly,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Graduate Students,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Postdocs,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Prospective Students,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Public,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Staff,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Student,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Trainees,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Category/Earth Institute,X-BEDEWORK-SHORTTITLE : values : text : Ocean & Climate Seminar Series | Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory,X-BEDEWORK-SUBMITTEDBY : values : text : st3408 for Ocean and Climate Physics Seminars (agrp_OCPS),X-BEDEWORK-CALSUITE : values : text : Ocean and Climate Physics Seminars,X-BEDEWORK-ADDITIONAL-INFO : values : text : January 28th, Jesse Cusack, Rutgers University, "Plume-generated internal gravity waves as drivers of melt at LeConte Glacier, Alaska"\nAbstract:\nTIt is commonly understood that melting at marine-terminating glaciers is enhanced by the fluid velocities in the vicinity of the ice-ocean boundary. Large velocities and high melt rates are thought to occur adjacent to highly turbulent subglacial discharge plumes. However, recent observations demonstrate that melt rates are also high far away from plumes, suggesting that other ocean processes may facilitate heat and salt fluxes to the ice-ocean interface. Using extensive in situ observations, as well as idealised large eddy simulations, we demonstrate that the subglacial discharge plume emanating from LeConte Glacier, Alaska, generates an energetic internal gravity wave field. The waves are persistent in time and fill the near-glacier fjord, accounting for ~ 50 % of the total observed kinetic energy near the ice-ocean boundary during the two-week September 2018 field campaign. They are characterised by coherent oscillations in velocity of magnitude 1 - 8 cm/s with a period of ~ 10 mins (close to the local buoyancy period) and a horizontal wavelength of 150 - 200 m. The signal was identified in two separate mooring records, one of which was located within 100 m of the terminus, suggesting that internal waves have the potential to enhance melting by driving flow directly at the ice-ocean interface. Accounting for wave velocities within a commonly used melt parameterisation, which assumes shear-driven boundary layer dynamics, results in a 40 - 80 % increase in the estimated melt rate relative to ambient (no wave) conditions.,X-BEDEWORK-DESCRIPTION-FORMAT : values : text : html

summary: Virtual Naloxone Training (Open to all Columbia community members)
description: <p>Columbia Health is a Registered Opioid Overdose Prevention Program, recognized by New York City and State Departments of Health. This designation came as part of a collaboration with researchers from the Mailman School of Public Health and the School of General Studies. As part of this work, Columbia Health is offering virtual Naloxone training via Zoom to members of the Columbia University community. Naloxone kits&nbsp;can be picked up from Columbia Health or mailed to participants upon completion of training.&nbsp;If you would like to learn more about the training please visit&nbsp;<a href="https://health.columbia.edu/content/naloxone-training">https://health.columbia.edu/content/naloxone-training</a>.</p>\n<p>Registration required.</p>\n<p><strong>Register for the March 21, 3&nbsp;- 4&nbsp;PM ET&nbsp;session:&nbsp;</strong><a href="https://bit.ly/3KmlFNq">https://bit.ly/3KmlFNq</a></p>

summary: Multi-Faith Fellowship
locationaddress: Earl Hall, 2980 Broadway, New York, NY 10027
description: <p>The Multi-Faith Fellowship provides the rare opportunity for genuine learning and community across faith traditions. Honesty, openness, and humility are core values that make the Multi-Faith Fellowship a unique experience in education and dialogue. Students from all schools and all traditions are welcome to join. Join us for&nbsp;dinner, discussion, and multi-faith dialogue every Wednesday night throughout the semester.&nbsp;</p>

xproperties: X-BEDEWORK-REGISTRATION-GUEST-ACCESS : values : text : 	email,X-BEDEWORK-IMAGE : values : text : /public/images/ocp-202108311134-202201161029.png,X-BEDEWORK-THUMB-IMAGE : values : text : 	/public/images/ocp-202108311134-202201161029-thumb.png,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Location/Lamont-Doherty,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Type/Seminar,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Alumni,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Faculty,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Family Friendly,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Graduate Students,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Postdocs,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Prospective Students,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Public,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Staff,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Student,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Events open to/Trainees,X-BEDEWORK-ALIAS : values : text : /user/agrp_calsuite-OCPS/Category/Earth Institute,X-BEDEWORK-SHORTTITLE : values : text : Ocean & Climate Seminar Series | Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory,X-BEDEWORK-SUBMITTEDBY : values : text : st3408 for Ocean and Climate Physics Seminars (agrp_OCPS),X-BEDEWORK-CALSUITE : values : text : Ocean and Climate Physics Seminars,X-BEDEWORK-ADDITIONAL-INFO : values : text : January 28th, Jesse Cusack, Rutgers University, "Plume-generated internal gravity waves as drivers of melt at LeConte Glacier, Alaska"\nAbstract:\nTIt is commonly understood that melting at marine-terminating glaciers is enhanced by the fluid velocities in the vicinity of the ice-ocean boundary. Large velocities and high melt rates are thought to occur adjacent to highly turbulent subglacial discharge plumes. However, recent observations demonstrate that melt rates are also high far away from plumes, suggesting that other ocean processes may facilitate heat and salt fluxes to the ice-ocean interface. Using extensive in situ observations, as well as idealised large eddy simulations, we demonstrate that the subglacial discharge plume emanating from LeConte Glacier, Alaska, generates an energetic internal gravity wave field. The waves are persistent in time and fill the near-glacier fjord, accounting for ~ 50 % of the total observed kinetic energy near the ice-ocean boundary during the two-week September 2018 field campaign. They are characterised by coherent oscillations in velocity of magnitude 1 - 8 cm/s with a period of ~ 10 mins (close to the local buoyancy period) and a horizontal wavelength of 150 - 200 m. The signal was identified in two separate mooring records, one of which was located within 100 m of the terminus, suggesting that internal waves have the potential to enhance melting by driving flow directly at the ice-ocean interface. Accounting for wave velocities within a commonly used melt parameterisation, which assumes shear-driven boundary layer dynamics, results in a 40 - 80 % increase in the estimated melt rate relative to ambient (no wave) conditions.,X-BEDEWORK-DESCRIPTION-FORMAT : values : text : html
